body:
@guozhangwang - re: restoration logic for standby tasks, it is all good. If the state store has logging disabled and doesn't have a topic, we don't try and restore it. It just gets added to the state store map. So no exceptions etc. I believe @norwood added this recently.
I've just added a test in `ProcessorStateManger` to make sure we know if this changes going forward
Feedback incorporated, and clean ups done. Are we good to merge?
Thanks for the PR, would it be possible to write a test for this?
@hachikuji can you please take another look?
Thanks @edoardocomar, will take another look soon. Can you please add a note to `upgrade.html`?
added a note to `upgrade.html` in the `upgrade_1010_notable` section
Thanks for the PR. I'll merge it as Jun has reviewed it and you have addressed the minor comments.

thanks @guozhangwang - i've been through your list above and added more informative exceptions.  w.r.t. backoff and retry in `RecordCollector` - how long do we backoff for and how many attempts? I've set it to 100ms backoff and 3 attempts. But, do we want to make this configurable?
Comments all addressed.
@ijuma - rebased, reduced lower bound to 1K and reran build successfully. Could we merge please?
Don't give up now @peterableda :)

@ijuma Updated. I did run MM system tests here: http://testing.confluent.io/confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results/?prefix=2016-09-27--001.1474950996--hachikuji--mm-default-new-consumer--e58dceb/. I also ran replication tests to verify that removing the "--new-consumer" flag worked correctly in the console consumer service: http://testing.confluent.io/confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results/?prefix=2016-09-27--001.1474959619--hachikuji--mm-default-new-consumer--e58dceb/.
closing this. will rebase with the original PR : https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/846

@junrao I have rebased with latest trunk. I think this patch should also address  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4074 with additional functionality of removing the topics listed under the /admin/delete_topics path in zookeeper. Would you mind taking another look?
@dguy @enothereska @mjsax @hjafarpour .
LGTM

@jjkoshy , @becketqin : Yes, having a separate callback.timeout seems easier to understand than piggybacking on metadata.age.ms.

About the bufferpool size in the producer in MM. I am curious how large you set it too. Batching is definitely the most effective way of getting higher throughput, but setting it larger beyond a certain point won't help any more and only increases the amount of the time a message is in the accumulator. For example, the default 32MB can still allow the producer to batch about 3KB per partition with 10K partitions.
@guozhangwang @enothereska - i just found this one.
LGTM aside from minor comment. Thanks for the cleanups!
@becketqin Other than the last couple minor comments, LGTM.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM. Merged it to trunk and 0.10.1 branches after a slight edit in `ReassignPartitionsCommand` to say 1 KB/s instead of 1 MB/s.

@hachikuji Thanks for the review. I updated the patch. I did not add validation to the constructor of `OffsetAndTimestamp` because internally the timestamp could be -1. We could add validation before we return the value, but it seems an over fitting test in the code itself and the unit test should have covered that.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.
@ijuma It is tricky to have unit test for mirror maker in this case. Do you think it worth a system test?
LGTM. Thanks for the updates!
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.

The unit test LGTM. Ran the whole suite locally without failure.

Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.
LGTM
I have addressed all outstanding items. Please re-review, thanks!

@dguy I think it is good enough for now and we can consider making it configurable in the future. There are other places such as `ProcesssStateManager.restore` where we also use hard-written backoffs for metadata refresh.
BTW could you rebase?
Thanks @rajinisivaram, LGTM. Did you measure the time it took before and after the changes?
Merged to 0.10.0 branch, @guozhangwang please close the PR when you can.

@becketqin, if the existing system test for MirrorMaker could be modified to test this scenario, that would be great. If it's a lot of work, we may have to split that into a separate JIRA and merge this PR as it is (so that it can be included in 0.10.1.0)

> Do we need to rename the variable to include timeout there somewhere given the new semantics?

Somehow I can't reply to the above inline. Here is my response: I renamed it to `consumer_init_timeout_sec`, and also introduce `consumer_start_timeout_sec` to be consistent with the semantics of `producer_start_timeout_sec`. What do you think?
Kickstarted the Jenkins system test [here](https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/560/).
Thanks. done
@ijuma Thank you for the review. On my laptop the total time for the three tests went down from 4min10sec to 1min40sec.
Thanks @rajinisivaram. I'll merge it soon.
Oh, I see it has been rebased since my review, so ignore that part. :)

@rajinisivaram, when I run the tests locally, they sometimes fail. For example:

``` text
kafka.api.UserQuotaTest > testQuotaOverrideDelete FAILED
    java.lang.AssertionError: Should have been throttled
```

@benstopford : For the throttled rate limit, a lower bound of 1KB/sec still seems arbitrary. Is the reason that a low rate doesn't work well because the default window may not be large enough? If so, it seems it's better to just require the rate limit to be at least 0, but document in the config that the window size may need to be adjusted if the rate is set too low.
I submitted a PR with a few minor clean-ups: https://github.com/becketqin/kafka/pull/2, LGTM otherwise.
Handling UTOP in consumerCoordinator handleResponse for fetchOffset and commitOffset, with more descriptive msg
@ijuma I have pushed a fix for the test failure. I have been running the tests in a loop, and it hasn't failed for me with the fix. Can you try it out? Thank you...
Review by @hachikuji.

All suggestions taken. 

The two of note are:
(A) Changing the type of the throttled list property in LogConfig to be LIST. That was a little fiddly. 
https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1906/commits/97acd19854b19564b9db4aac3166d18fdcd9ce0f
(B) Adding validation to the reassignment command to ensure we only move partitions that exist. 
https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1906/commits/faedb50f8646a24da94bac2ed047dcda326bdb8d
The rest were straight forward.
LGTM with Ismael's minor tweaks. Great work getting KIP-79 ready in a hurry for this release!
@guozhangwang updated. Thanks
@ijuma Can you take a look at this?  PR #1926 may be related. Thank you...
Thanks for the PR, LGTM.
@rajinisivaram I'm wondering why we don't use `ObjectName.quote` to make the tag values safe generically. This is what is done internally in the Yammer `MetricName.createMBeanName` method.
Thanks @hachikuji and @ijuma The changes LGTM.
@becketqin I'll merge this as soon as you accept Ismael's PR.

Result of Jenkins branch builder for this run [is here](http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3.amazonaws.com/2016-09-28--001.1475040128--apurvam--throttling-tests--1f55670/report.html).

Only one test failure, that of `TestMirrorMakerService`. Looking at the stack trace, it seems unrelated: it was terminated by a `KeyboardInterrupt` somehow while spinning up zookeeper.
@apurvam FYI this is the job that I cancelled last night with `SIGINT`. The final error shows up as `KeyboardInterrupt` because that is how the python interpreter translates `SIGINT`
@granders yep. I just looked at the results, and only 34 tests out of 200+ ran. I kicked of another run a little while back, but it's waiting in the queue.

And then in `KafkaProducer`, a more informative exception

```
IllegalArgumentException(String.format("Invalid partition given with record: %d is not in the range [0...%d].", partition, lastPartition));
```

will be thrown.
@ijuma @hachikuji @dguy @enothereska
@guozhangwang Pushed new changes.

Ping @junrao for review. The deadlock we're attempting to prevent occurs in the following scenario:
1. Thread 1 acquires lock A and invokes `DelayedOperationPurgatory.watchForOperation` which attempts to synchronize on the internal list of watchers for the corresponding key.
2. Thread 2 is holding the lock on the internal list of watchers for the same key and invokes `tryComplete` which attempts to acquire lock A.

To fix this generally, we should avoid holding any purgatory locks when invoking `tryComplete`. To accommodate this, I've changed the collection from a `LinkedList` to an immutable `Vector` which makes it safe to iterate over the operations and invoke `tryComplete` without a lock. 

The main concern from an efficiency perspective is that we now need to do a copy when purging completed operations. My thought was that this would be OK in practice since delayed operations would tend to be completed together, but that may not always be true I guess for delayed fetches which have different `fetchMinBytes` requirements.
@apurvam Your branch builder job is now running [here](https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/562/console)
@hachikuji Done. I'll update the KIP wiki for the new error code.
Thanks, tests passed locally. Merged to trunk.
@ijuma It probably can be added to the existing mirror maker integration test. But I am not sure how long that would take given that I do not have much experience with integration test.
@hachikuji I updated the PR to only add `MaxPermSize` if the JDK version is lower than Java 8.

@hjafarpour I ran the unit test locally and the Jenkins failures seems to be pretty consistent, were your local unit test run passed?

```
KafkaStreamsTest. testStartAndClose
KStreamAggregationDedupIntegrationTest. shouldReduce
KStreamAggregationDedupIntegrationTest. shouldReduceWindowed
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldAggregateWindowed[0]
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldAggregateWindowed[1]
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldAggregate[0]
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldAggregate[1]
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldCount[0]
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldCount[1]
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldReduceWindowed[0]
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldReduceWindowed[1]
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldReduce[0]
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest. shouldReduce[1]
QueryableStateIntegrationTest. queryOnRebalance[0]
QueryableStateIntegrationTest. queryOnRebalance[1]
ResetIntegrationTest. testReprocessingFromScratchAfterReset
StreamPartitionAssignorTest. testAssignWithStates
```
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1. I changed the title slightly, hopefully it's reasonable.
@kkonstantine LGTM. Let me know when you've validated existing system tests (a subset of them is probably fine).

I think raising a different exception if a closed iterator is used might be a good idea. For example, after a rebalanced, user might want to issues new "key discovery" and start over -- if we just return `false` or raise `NoSuchElementException` it is not clear that not all keys got returned and thus user might only get part of the stuff done they actually wanted to do.

Otherwise LGTM.
LGTM. Merging to trunk, 0.10.1 and 0.10.0.
Please review @hjafarpour @guozhangwang @enothereska @dguy @miguno
The title change looks good. Thanks a lot for the review @hachikuji @ijuma
@jeyhunkarimov @dguy What is the status of this PR?
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1 branches.

@mjsax i was waiting for KIP-63 to go in before looking any further at this. This will have be affected by some of the changes from KIP-63 and they need to be thought through. I was hoping to get back to @jeyhunkarimov early next week.
@guozhangwang - looks like the test failures might be related? Possibly just test setup, but...
Thanks @mjsax - i agree with throwing an exception. Change pushed
Thanks for the PR, LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.1 branches after a few trivial tweaks. Tests passed locally.
@junrao @ijuma have changed the bound to be 0 and adjusted the documentation appropriately. I pushed this into PR https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1932

@hachikuji Thank you for the review. Makes sense to quote tags instead of replacing :, have updated the code to do that. The code adds quotes when necessary (ipv6 address for instance), leaving other tags unchanged.
LGTM

@guozhangwang - we have observed in our tests that this is an issue, i.e, not closing the iterators was causing the number of open files to increase for ever. I've verified that this is not the case with this patch.

@apurvam there were some system test failures like the following:

``` text
test_id:    2016-09-28--001.kafkatest.tests.core.throttling_test.ThrottlingTest.test_throttled_reassignment.bounce_brokers=True
status:     FAIL
run time:   2 minutes 12.935 seconds


    {'ProducerPerformanceService-0-140201794908624-worker-1': Exception('No output from ProducerPerformance',)}
Traceback (most recent call last):
```

There are also unrelated failures that were fixed by https://github.com/apache/kafka/commit/a6f3cf56b3ce5c97e89f4b80c34d54ea608950ee

I rebased Apurva's branch to include Jason's fix and started a new system tests build (while the US is still sleeping):

https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder-2/103

Thanks for the patch. LGTM. In the common case, the watch list per key should be small. However, I agree it would be useful to do some perf testing to see if there is noticeable additional overhead due to copying the watch list.
rebased/merged and fixed spurious test failure
3 failures

Thanks @hachikuji. A number of current tests using the updated class have run successfully. 
Also the PR has been rebased.

@dguy I just use default Intellij formatting with some adjustments to meet code style checks of the build -- I thought that is the default we use? No? I don't care about the formatting, but I strongly recommend that we agree on a unique formatting and use the same auto-formatting rules...

Completely agree, that formatting changes in PR should be avoided.
Quick question: this only helps when the DoS is unintentional right?
Yes this mostly helps against badly configured "good" clients.

I think it would be good to think about how we should handle "bad" clients. Then we can decide if it's the right solution for both cases or if it makes sense to have a separate one for "good" clients.
@dguy @enothereska You are right, I will fix them.
